repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Following up the discussion on the mailing list. I got to the point where I can use the new syntax:

- [X] Write a srctree test that creates various types of external ctypedef classes, add one that overrides a python-level @property with a cython one. This is a continuation of the test added in #2629 
- [X] Add `decorator` child and outer attributes to `CFuncDefNode`. ~I simply copied this from `DefNode`, is it required?~ - yes, seems to be required
- [X] ~Add a `DecoratorTransform.visit_CFuncDefNode` function based on `DecoratorTransform.visit_DefNode` and verify it is reached while parsing the `ctypedef class`.~
- [x] ~Found the point at which the attribute lookup should become a property function call (I think) is in `AttributeNode.analyse_attribute`. But it seems the entry is wrong, I need to either~ 

- ~fix the entry in `PropertyNode.analyse_declarations` and somehow make sure it is used instead of the old entry~
- ~change the code in `CFuncDefNode.analyse_declarations` and remove the `DecoratorTransform.visit_CFuncDefNode` function~

Any hints would be welcome.

Edit: added a new pass, ~still not working~

comment_data.body: This XXX is hit if I remove `DecoratorTransform.visit_CFuncDefNode`, and the entry is registered properly for attribute lookup for `Foo.field0`, `Foo.field1`, `Foo.field2`, but then of course fails since the entry is a function `int (Foo)` not the function call.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2339,6 +2340,16 @@ def code_object(self):
         return self.py_func.code_object if self.py_func else None
 
     def analyse_declarations(self, env):
+        if self.decorators:
+            for decorator in self.decorators:
+                func = decorator.decorator
+                if func.is_name:
+                    if func.name == 'classmethod' or func.name == 'staticmethod':
+                        error(self.pos, "Cannot handle these decorators yet")
+                    if func.name == 'property':
+                        # XXX DO SOMETHING HERE???
+                        pass
+

comment_data.body: The entry from `env.declare_property` is not being overridden by the later entry from the body.stats[0].entry, even if I enable the code here
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -5023,6 +5034,13 @@ def analyse_declarations(self, env):

         self.entry.scope.directives = env.directives
         self.body.analyse_declarations(self.entry.scope)
+        # XXX DO SOMETHING HERE???
+        if 0 and self.is_wrapper:
+            entry = self.body.stats[0].entry
+            entry.is_property = 1
+            entry.doc = self.doc
+            env.property_entries[-1] = entry
+            env.entries[self.name] = entry

comment_data.body: What is AnalyzeTypes? I turned on DebugFlags.debug_verbose_pipeline (since I am running a srctree test which runs cythonize in a subprocess, I needed to actually edit the file) and see a AnalyseDeclarationsTransform which is calling PropertyNode.analyse_declarations which is calling this function (CFuncDefNode.analyse_declarations) via line 5036 since it is part of the PropertyNode.body. But I couldn't figure out how to override the results of env.declare_property on line 5034 to make the CFuncDefNode's entry into the one called for `field0`

comment_data.body:
`child_attrs` is used for the tree traversal during transformations. Nodes (and lists of nodes) in these attributes will be visited, in the given order. Attributes that are not in this list will not be traversed.

`outer_attrs` is a subset that semantically belongs to the outer scope (or namespace). Functions have their own internal scope, but decorators are not evaluated in that scope but the outer one. I think the additions above are correct.

+    child_attrs = ["base_type", "declarator", "body", "py_func_stat", "decorators"]
+    outer_attrs = ["decorators"]

comment_data.body: The `AnalyseDeclarationsTransform` cannot currently replace tree nodes (at least not the one it currently handles). Robert meant the `AnalyseExpressionsTransform`, which can do that but might run too late. I'd say, somewhere between the `AnalyseDeclarationsTransform` and the `ControlFlowAnalysis` steps would be the right place for a new transform that replaces these property usages.

comment_data.body:
This should probably say `self.entry.type`  which suggests that this unused code is at least not tested.
Also, instead of using `getattr()` on a type, we normally set a class attribute somewhere in the type class hierarchy (or the `Entry`, or the `Node` hierarchy, ) and then override it with an instance attribute where necessary.

         self.analyse_attribute(env)
         if self.entry and self.entry.is_cmethod and not self.is_called:
-#            error(self.pos, "C method can only be called")
+            if getattr(self.entry, 'is_cgetter', False):

comment_data.body: I actually wonder if `is_cgetter` should be a feature of the type or of the entry. If the latter, then the code that calls this method should do the checking here. It doesn't really feel like a type specific thing to me, at least

comment_data.body: Shouldn't this use the `#define` macros above?

We should test that the C level access is used here and not the Python level access. Not sure if [tree assertions](https://github.com/cython/cython/wiki/HackerGuide#parse-tree-assertions) work in srctree tests (they might not), but they seem necessary here, give that the Python interface is the same.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -78,32 +111,89 @@ cdef extern from "foo_nominal.h":
             int field2 "f2"
 
 def sum(Foo f):
-    # the f.__getattr__('field0') is replaced in c by f->f0
+    # Note - not a cdef function but compiling the f.__getattr__('field0')
+    # notices the alias and replaces the __getattr__ in c by f->f0 anyway
     return f.field0 + f.field1 + f.field2
 
+######## getter1.pyx ########
+
+# Access base Foo fields from C via getter functions
+
+
+cdef extern from "foo.h":
+    ctypedef class foo_extension.Foo [object FooStructOpaque, check_size ignore]:
+        @property
+        cdef int field0(self):
+            return PyFoo_GET0M(self)
+
+        @property
+        cdef int field1(self):
+            return PyFoo_Get1F(self)
+
+        @property
+        cdef int field2(self):
+            return PyFoo_GET2M(self)
+
+    int PyFoo_GET0M(Foo);  # this is actually a macro !
+    int PyFoo_Get1F(Foo);
+    int PyFoo_GET2M(Foo);  # this is actually a macro !
+
+def sum(Foo f):
+    # Note - not a cdef function but compiling the f.__getattr__('field0')
+    # notices the getter and replaces the __getattr__ in c by PyFoo_GET anyway
+    return f.field0 + f.field1 + f.field2

comment_data.body: I think returning the node (and not a single element list) should be fine here. Actually, I'd a) use `break` instead of duplicating the `return` code, and b) use a search loop that exits and then does stuff, rather than doing everything in the loop. (And c) use a helper to find the right decorator.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -2239,6 +2239,25 @@ def visit_IndexNode(self, node):
             node = node.base
         return node
 
+class ReplacePropertyNode(CythonTransform):
+    def visit_CFuncDefNode(self, node):
+        if not node.decorators:
+            return node
+        # transform @property decorators on ctypedef class functions
+        for decorator_node in node.decorators[::-1]:
+            decorator = decorator_node.decorator
+            if decorator.is_name and decorator.name == 'property':
+                if len(node.decorators) > 1:
+                    return self._reject_decorated_property(node, decorator_node)
+                # Mark the node as a cgetter
+                node.type.is_cgetter = True
+                # Add a func_cname to be output instead of the attribute
+                node.entry.func_cname = node.body.stats[0].value.function.name
+                # done - remove the decorator node
+                node.decorators.remove(decorator_node)
+                return [node]
+        return [node]

How can I transfer the `is_cgetter` set in `ReplacePropertyNode.visit_CFuncDefNode` to the `AttributeNode`that shares the entry?

comment_data.body:
Through the `Entry`. :) Symbol table entries are shared within their scope.
Add a class attribute `is_cgetter = False` to the `Entry` class and then set it to `True` on the instance where you need it.

+        if type2.is_cfunction and type2.is_cgetter:
+            type2 = type2.return_type

comment_data.body: Maybe we should only set `entry.is_cgetter` and not `entry.is_cmethod` for these properties ? If `@propertiy` is used, I think it's intended to make the entry non-callable, i.e. not a method.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -6976,11 +6976,7 @@ def analyse_as_ordinary_attribute_node(self, env, target):
         self.obj = self.obj.analyse_types(env)
         self.analyse_attribute(env)
         if self.entry and self.entry.is_cmethod and not self.is_called:

comment_data.body: Ah, yes, that's much better.

Hmm, this refactoring doesn't look helpful. The return value means different things inside of the `analyse_decorator()` method, doesn't have an explanatory name here, and is basically ignored. That's rather obscure code.
Also, `analyse_decorator()` essentially consists of two code paths, but I have to look through the longest path in order to understand the shorter one (the one that says "nothing to do").

So, first of all, I think this whole transformation can be merged into the `DecoratorTransform`. Then, the `visit_DefNode()` method over there should share some code with `visit_CFuncDefNode()`. They will be doing different things in the end, but the search loop, conditions and error handling are the same, so they should only be implemented once. I propose to write a shared helper method that searches an `@property` (or `@setter` etc.) decorator, and, if found (and it's the only one), returns it, so that the two visitor methods can deal with it in their own ways. For all errors, it should just call `error()`. Failing to find a property decorator, returning `None` is a good enough signal to the caller.

Note that `_reject_decorated_property()` actually raises a `CompileError` in the `error()` call, so it does not actually return (I admit that that's not obvious either).

-            if decorator.is_name and decorator.name == 'property':
-                if len(node.decorators) > 1:
-                    return self._reject_decorated_property(node, decorator_node)
-                # Mark the node as a cgetter
-                node.type.is_cgetter = True
-                # Add a func_cname to be output instead of the attribute
-                node.entry.func_cname = node.body.stats[0].value.function.name
-                # done - remove the decorator node
+            _node = self.analyse_decorator(node, decorator_node.decorator)
+            if _node:

comment_data.body:

Edit: `node.type` is a `CFuncType`

comment_data.body:
The call chain is `Nodes.CFuncDefNode.analyse_declarations` finds the property decorator and later calls `env.declare_cfunction` where `env` is any one of `Scope`, `CClassScope` or .`CppClassScope`. If I remove the kwarg from `Symtab.Scope`, how do I adjust the call in `analyse_declarations`?

Also I see that I never handle the kwarg in `Symtab.CppClassScope.declare_cfunction`. Do I need to add a test for a `CppClass` that uses a `@property` to define a getter? I didn't really grok that `CppClass` is different from `CClass`

comment_data.body: In the test, `Scope.declare_cfunction` is called once from `CFuncDefNode.analyse_declarations` for `__pyx_unpickle_Foo__set_state`. Removing the kwarg means checking the `env` type before the call

comment_data.body: After staring at the examples of `cdef cppclass` I think use of a `@property` decorator to replace a `cdef attribute` getter with a c function is not needed, so the code path in `Symtab.CppClassScope.declare_cfunction` should never have `is_property` be True. Do you agree, and should I assert `is_property == False` at the top of this function?

comment_data.body: I think ``CppClassScope``, ``ModuleScope`` and ``Scope`` should not have the parameter in their ``declare_cfunction()`` implementation at all.

comment_data.body:
I would prefer having a simple version of the Rectangle C++ source here, rather than looking it up in some far away directory through brittle relative paths. You can use [verbatim C code](http://docs.cython.org/en/latest/src/userguide/external_C_code.html#including-verbatim-c-code) for that.

Also, I'm currently enabling the C++ tests on appveyor (#2797). Once that works and I merged it, you can merge the latest master into your feature branch to let appveyor run this test.

commit.message: WIP ENH: allow @property decorator on external ctypedef classes
ENH: handle c-level property decorator to produce a cfunc call
BUG: fix test to use correct macros, functions for c-level getters
whoops, staticmethod is a valid cdef decorator
MAINT: make attribute names unique to prove c-getters are being used
MAINT: refactor: is_cgetter now lives on the entry, use find_decorator
MAINT: localize is_property handling to CFuncDefNode.analyse_declarations

milestone.description:
Goals:
 New version scheme: 3.x instead of 0.x.
 Change default `language_level` from `2` to `3`.
 Change default for `binding` directive from `False` to `True`.
 Fix some Python compatibility issues (if possible, allowing for breaking changes).

title: ENH: allow @property decorator on external ctypedef classes
